panelsplit.cross_validation package#

Submodules#

panelsplit.cross_validation.panelsplit module#

class panelsplit.cross_validation.panelsplit.PanelSplit(periods, unique_periods=None, snapshots=None, n_splits=2, gap=0, test_size=1, max_train_size=None)#

Bases: object

PanelSplit implements panel data cross-validation using time series splits.

Parameters:

  • periods (pd.Series, pd.Index, or np.ndarray) – A collection of periods for each observation.

  • unique_periods (array-like, optional) – An array-like object containing unique periods. If None, the unique periods will be computed from periods. Default is None.

  • snapshots (pd.Series, optional) – A Series defining the snapshot for each observation. Default is None.

  • n_splits (int, optional) – Number of splits for TimeSeriesSplit. Default is 2.

  • gap (int, optional) – Gap between the training and testing sets. Default is 0.

  • test_size (int, optional) – Size of the test set. Default is 1.

  • max_train_size (int, optional) – Maximum size for a single training set. Default is None.

Notes

This class is designed for panel data where cross-validation splits must respect temporal ordering.

gen_snapshots(data, period_col=None)#

Generate snapshots for each cross-validation split.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) – The DataFrame from which snapshots are generated.

  • period_col (str, optional) – The column name (or index) in data to derive the snapshot period. If both an index and a column in data are named period_col, the index is used by default.

Returns:

A concatenated DataFrame containing snapshots for each split. Each snapshot includes a ‘split’ column (indicating the split number) and, if period_col is provided, a ‘snapshot_period’ column.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

Examples

>>> import pandas as pd
>>> data = pd.DataFrame({
... 'value': [10, pd.NA, 30],
... 'period': [1, 2, 3],
... }).astype('Int32')
>>> ps = PanelSplit(periods=data['period'], n_splits=2)
>>> snapshots = ps.gen_snapshots(data, period_col='period')
>>> print(snapshots)
   value  period  split  snapshot_period
0     10       1      0                2
1   <NA>       2      0                2
0     10       1      1                3
1   <NA>       2      1                3
2     30       3      1                3
gen_test_labels(labels)#

Generate testing set labels based on the provided labels.

Parameters:

labels (pd.Index, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame, or np.ndarray) – The labels corresponding to the observations.

Returns:

The labels for the testing set.

Return type:

Same type as labels

Examples

>>> import pandas as pd
>>> periods = pd.Series([1, 2, 3])
>>> labels = np.array(['a', 'b', 'c'])
>>> ps = PanelSplit(periods=periods, n_splits=2)
>>> test_labels = ps.gen_test_labels(labels)
>>> test_labels
array(['b', 'c'], dtype='<U1')
gen_train_labels(labels)#

Generate training set labels based on the provided labels.

Parameters:

labels (pd.Index, pd.Series, pd.DataFrame, or np.ndarray) – The labels corresponding to the observations.

Returns:

The labels for the training set.

Return type:

Same type as labels

Examples

>>> import pandas as pd
>>> periods = pd.Series([1, 2, 3])
>>> labels = np.array(['a', 'b', 'c'])
>>> ps = PanelSplit(periods=periods, n_splits=2)
>>> train_labels = ps.gen_train_labels(labels)
>>> train_labels
array(['a', 'b'], dtype='<U1')
get_n_splits(X=None, y=None, groups=None)#

Get the number of splits.

Parameters:

  • X (object, optional) – Ignored; included for compatibility.

  • y (object, optional) – Ignored; included for compatibility.

  • groups (object, optional) – Ignored; included for compatibility.

Returns:

The number of splits.

Return type:

int

Examples

>>> import pandas as pd
>>> periods = pd.Series([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])
>>> ps = PanelSplit(periods=periods, n_splits=3)
>>> ps.get_n_splits()
3
split(X=None, y=None, groups=None)#

Generate training and testing indices for each cross-validation split.

Parameters:

  • X (object, optional) – Ignored; included for compatibility.

  • y (object, optional) – Ignored; included for compatibility.

  • groups (object, optional) – Ignored; included for compatibility.

Returns:

A list of tuples, where each tuple contains: (train_indices, test_indices) as boolean arrays.

Return type:

list of tuple of np.ndarray

Examples

>>> period = pd.Series([1, 2, 3])
>>> y = pd.Series([0, np.nan, 1])
>>> ps = PanelSplit(periods=period, n_splits=2)
>>> splits = ps.split()
>>> for train, test in splits:
...     print("Train:", train, "Test:", test)
Train: [ True False False] Test: [False  True False]
Train: [ True  True False] Test: [False False  True]
>>> ps_modified = drop_splits(ps, y)
>>> splits_modified = ps_modified.split()
Dropping split 0 as either the test or train set is either empty or contains only one unique value.
>>> for train, test in splits_modified:
...    print("Train:", train, "Test:", test)
Train: [ True  True False] Test: [False False  True]
panelsplit.cross_validation.panelsplit.drop_splits(cv, y)#

Drop cross-validation splits if either the training or testing set is empty or contains only one unique value.

Parameters:

  • cv (list) – A list of tuples, where each tuple contains (train_indices, test_indices) as boolean arrays. The object is expected to have an attribute n_splits (an integer) and support the pop method.

  • y (pd.Series) – Series of shape (n_samples,) containing target values.

Returns:

The modified list of splits with the problematic splits removed.

Return type:

list

Examples

>>> import pandas as pd
>>> data = pd.DataFrame({
... 'value': [10, pd.NA, 30],
... 'period': [1, 2, 3],
... }).astype('Int32')
>>> ps = PanelSplit(periods=periods, n_splits=2)
>>> drop_splits(ps, data['value'])
Dropping split 0 as either the test or train set is either empty or contains only one unique value.
